s0001.chinese: 高祖，沛豐邑中陽里人也，姓劉氏。
s0001.literal: Gaozu was a person from Zhongyang Village, Fengyi Town, Pei County, and his surname was Liu.
s0001.idiomatic: Gaozu was a native of Zhongyang Village in Fengyi Township, Pei County, and bore the surname Liu.

s0002.chinese: 母媼嘗息大澤之陂，夢與神遇。
s0002.literal: His mother the old woman once rested by the dike of a great marsh, and dreamed that she encountered a god.
s0002.idiomatic: His mother once rested by the bank of a vast marsh and dreamed of meeting a divine being.

s0003.chinese: 是時雷電晦冥，父太公往視，則見交龍於上。
s0003.literal: At this time there was thunder and lightning, dark and obscure; his father Taigong went to look, and then saw two dragons copulating above.
s0003.idiomatic: At that moment, thunder crashed and lightning flashed in the darkened sky. His father Taigong went to investigate and saw two dragons entwined overhead.

s0004.literal: Soon after she became pregnant, and then gave birth to Gaozu.
s0004.idiomatic: Soon she conceived and gave birth to Gaozu.

s0005.chinese: 高祖為人，隆準而龍顏，美須髯，左股有七十二黑子。
s0005.literal: Gaozu as a person had a high nose and dragon-like face, beautiful beard and whiskers, and on his left thigh there were seventy-two black moles.
s0005.idiomatic: Gaozu had a prominent nose, a face like a dragon, magnificent whiskers, and seventy-two black moles on his left thigh.

s0006.literal: He was magnanimous, benevolent, and loved people; his thoughts were open and clear.
s0006.idiomatic: He was generous, kind, and loved others, with an open and magnanimous spirit.

s0007.chinese: 常有大度，不事家人生產作 業。
s0007.literal: He constantly had great breadth of mind, did not engage in the household production occupations.
s0007.idiomatic: He always showed great magnanimity and never bothered with household chores or farming.

s0008.chinese: 及壯，試吏，為泗上亭長，廷中吏無所不狎侮。
s0008.literal: When he reached adulthood, he tried being an official, became the pavilion chief of Sishang, and among the officials in the court there was none he did not treat familiarly and insult.
s0008.idiomatic: Upon reaching adulthood, he became a minor official, serving as the chief of a rural pavilion. Among the court officials, there was none he didn't treat with casual familiarity and mock.

s0009.literal: He was fond of wine and sex.

s0010.chinese: 常從王媼、武負貰酒，時飲醉臥，武負、王媼見其上常有怪。
s0010.literal: He often borrowed wine from Wang Ao and Wu Fu; at times he drank until drunk and lay down, and Wu Fu and Wang Ao saw that above him there was often something strange.
s0010.idiomatic: He frequently borrowed wine from Granny Wang and Wu Fu. Sometimes he'd drink himself into a stupor and collapse, and both Wu Fu and Granny Wang noticed strange apparitions hovering above him.

s0011.chinese: 高祖每酤留飲，酒讎數倍。
s0011.literal: Gaozu every time he bought wine would keep drinking, the wine debts several times.
s0011.idiomatic: Whenever Gaozu bought wine, he'd stay and drink, racking up debts several times the amount.

s0012.chinese: 及見怪，歲 竟，此兩家常折券棄責。
s0012.literal: When they saw the strange thing, the year ended, these two families constantly tore up the bonds and abandoned the debts.
s0012.idiomatic: When they witnessed the strange phenomenon, at year's end these two families would tear up the IOUs and forgive the debts.

s0013.chinese: 高祖常繇咸陽，縱觀秦皇帝，喟然大息，曰：「嗟乎，大丈夫當如此矣！」
s0013.literal: Gaozu often passed through Xianyang, gazed freely at the Qin emperor, sighed deeply, said: 'Alas, a great man should be like this!'
s0013.idiomatic: Gaozu often passed through Xianyang and gazed at the Qin emperor. He sighed deeply and said, 'Ah, this is how a true man should live!'

s0014.chinese: 單父人呂公善沛令，辟仇，從之客，因家焉。
s0014.literal: The Shanfu person Lü Gong was on good terms with the Pei magistrate, avoided enmity, followed him as guest, and therefore settled his family there.
s0014.idiomatic: Lü Gong from Shanfu was friends with the magistrate of Pei. To avoid his enemies, he became the magistrate's guest and settled his family there.

s0015.chinese: 沛中豪傑吏聞令有重客，皆往賀。
s0015.literal: The Pei middle heroes and officials heard the magistrate had an important guest, all went to congratulate.
s0015.idiomatic: When Pei's elite officials heard the magistrate had an important guest, they all went to offer congratulations.

s0016.chinese: 蕭何為主吏，主進，令諸 大夫曰：「進不滿千錢，坐之堂下。」
s0016.literal: Xiao He was the chief clerk, in charge of receiving guests, ordered the various grandees saying: 'Gifts not reaching a thousand cash, seat them below the hall.'
s0016.idiomatic: Xiao He served as chief clerk handling receptions. He instructed the other officials: 'Anyone whose gift is less than a thousand cash must sit below the main hall.'

s0017.chinese: 高祖為亭長，素易諸吏，乃紿為謁曰「賀錢萬」，實不持一錢。
s0017.literal: Gaozu was the pavilion chief, usually treated the various officials casually, then deceived them by announcing 'Congratulations money ten thousand', actually did not bring one cash.
s0017.idiomatic: Gaozu was the local sheriff and usually treated officials casually. He tricked them by announcing 'Ten thousand cash congratulations gift' but actually brought nothing.

s0018.chinese: 謁入，呂公大驚，起，迎之門。
s0018.literal: The announcement entered, Lü Gong greatly astonished, rose, welcomed him at the gate.
s0018.idiomatic: When the announcement came in, Lü Gong was astonished. He rose and went to welcome Gaozu at the gate.

s0019.chinese: 呂公者，好相人，見高祖狀 貌，因重敬之，引入坐上坐。
s0019.literal: Lü Gong was fond of physiognomy, saw Gaozu's appearance and bearing, therefore greatly respected him, led him in to sit in the seat of honor.
s0019.idiomatic: Lü Gong loved reading faces. When he saw Gaozu's features, he was greatly impressed and seated him in the place of honor.

s0020.chinese: 蕭何曰：「劉季固多大言，少成事。」
s0020.literal: Xiao He said: 'Liu Ji indeed much big talk, little accomplishes things.'
s0020.idiomatic: Xiao He said, 'Liu Ji talks big but accomplishes little.'

s0021.chinese: 高祖因狎侮諸客，遂坐上坐，無所詘。
s0021.literal: Gaozu because of familiarly insulting the various guests, then sat in the seat of honor, and was not at all yielding.
s0021.idiomatic: Because he treated all the guests with casual familiarity and mockery, Gaozu ended up taking the seat of honor without yielding to anyone.

s0022.chinese: 酒闌，呂公因目固留高祖。
s0022.literal: When the wine was exhausted, Lü Gong therefore gave a meaningful glance and firmly detained Gaozu.
s0022.idiomatic: As the banquet wound down, Lü Gong exchanged glances and insisted on keeping Gaozu behind.

s0024.chinese: 呂公曰：「臣少好 相人，相人多矣，無如季相，願季自愛。
s0024.literal: Lü Gong said: 'I from youth have liked physiognomy, have read physiognomy for many people, none are like Ji's physiognomy, I hope Ji will take care of himself.
s0024.idiomatic: Lü Gong said, 'Since I was young, I've loved reading faces. I've analyzed countless people, but none have the remarkable features of Ji. I hope you'll take good care of yourself.

s0025.literal: I have a young daughter, I wish her to be Ji's broom and mat concubine.'
s0025.idiomatic: I have a young daughter whom I would like to offer as your humble wife.'

s0026.chinese: 酒罷，呂媼怒呂公曰：「公始常欲奇此女，與貴人。
s0026.literal: When the wine was finished, Lü Ao was angry at Lü Gong and said: 'You at first constantly wanted to make this girl exceptional, and give her to a noble person.
s0026.idiomatic: After the banquet ended, Lü Ao angrily confronted Lü Gong: 'You always wanted to treat this girl specially and marry her to someone noble.

s0027.chinese: 沛令善公，求之不與，何自妄許與劉季？」
s0027.literal: The Pei magistrate was on good terms with you, sought her and you didn't give, why arbitrarily promise her to Liu Ji?'
s0027.idiomatic: The magistrate of Pei was your good friend and asked for her hand, but you refused. Why arbitrarily promise her to Liu Ji?'

s0028.chinese: 呂公曰：「此非兒女子所知。」
s0028.literal: Lü Gong said: 'This is not something that women and children know.'
s0028.idiomatic: Lü Gong replied, 'This is not something women and children understand.'

s0029.literal: In the end he gave her to Gaozu.
s0029.idiomatic: In the end, she was married to Gaozu.

s0030.chinese: 呂公女即呂后也，生孝惠帝、魯元公主。
s0030.literal: Lü Gong's daughter was namely Empress Lü, she gave birth to Emperor Xiaohui and Princess Lu Yuan.
s0030.idiomatic: Lü Gong's daughter became Empress Lü, and she bore Emperor Xiaohui and Princess Lu Yuan.

s0031.literal: Gaozu once took leave and returned to the fields.
s0031.idiomatic: Gaozu once took leave to return to his farm.

s0032.chinese: 呂后與兩子居田中，有一老父過請飲，呂后因餔之。
s0032.literal: Empress Lü and her two children lived in the fields, there was an old man who passed by requesting drink, Empress Lü therefore fed him.
s0032.idiomatic: Empress Lü lived in the countryside with her two children. One day an old man passed by asking for a drink, and she fed him.

s0033.chinese: 老父相后曰：「夫人天下貴人 也。」
s0033.literal: The old man read Empress Lü's physiognomy and said: 'Madam is a noble person of the realm.'
s0033.idiomatic: The old man read Empress Lü's face and said, 'Madam, you will be the most noble woman in the empire.'

s0034.chinese: 令相兩子，見孝惠帝，曰：「夫人所以貴者，乃此男也。」
s0034.literal: He had him read the physiognomy of the two children, seeing Emperor Xiaohui, he said: 'The reason madam will be noble is this boy.'
s0034.idiomatic: He then read the faces of her two children. Looking at Emperor Xiaohui, he said, 'The reason you will be noble, madam, is this boy.'

s0035.literal: Reading Princess Lu Yuan's physiognomy, also all noble.
s0035.idiomatic: When he read Princess Lu Yuan's face, he said she too would be noble.

s0036.chinese: 老父已去，高祖適從旁舍來，呂后具言客有過，相我子母皆大貴。
s0036.literal: The old man had already left, Gaozu just then came from the neighboring shed, Empress Lü fully told him that a guest had passed by, who read physiognomy for me and my children, saying we would all be greatly noble.
s0036.idiomatic: The old man had already departed when Gaozu returned from the neighboring cottage. Empress Lü told him everything about the visitor who had read their faces and predicted great nobility for them all.

s0037.idiomatic: Gaozu asked where he had gone. 'Not far,' she replied.

s0038.literal: Then he pursued and caught up, questioned the old man.
s0038.idiomatic: He went after him and caught up, then questioned the old man.

s0039.chinese: 老父曰：「鄉者夫人兒子皆以君，君相貴不可言。」
s0039.literal: The old man said: 'Just now madam's children all take after you, your lordship's physiognomy is noble beyond words.'
s0039.idiomatic: The old man said, 'Just now I saw that your children all resemble you, my lord. Your features indicate nobility beyond description.'

s0040.chinese: 高祖乃謝曰：「誠如父言，不敢忘德。」
s0040.literal: Gaozu then thanked him saying: 'Truly as father says, I dare not forget the favor.'
s0040.idiomatic: Gaozu thanked him profusely: 'Your words are truly prophetic, sir. I won't forget your kindness.'
